title: R41010
content: The Supreme Court has held in abeyance the question of whether a demonstration of actual innocence would render a defendant's execution unconstitutional. Davis's habeas petition was transferred to the U.S. District Court, which concluded that while the constitutional right exists, Davis's case did not warrant relief. The Supreme Court declined to review the lower court opinion, leaving the underlying question unresolved. Davis was convicted of murder, obstruction of a police officer, aggravated assault, and possession of a firearm during a felony, involving the shooting of a police officer. Davis was convicted of murder of a police officer in his duty and sentenced to death. He petitioned for habeas relief based on constitutional claims and actual innocence, but his petitions were rejected. The district court and court of appeals rejected Davis's constitutional claims. He then petitioned the Georgia courts for a new trial based on witness recantations and new evidence, but the Georgia Supreme Court affirmed the denial. Davis sought approval from the federal court of appeals for a second habeas petition, arguing his innocence, but it was denied due to lack of new evidence. The majority rejected Davis's application for a second habeas petition, stating it lacked newly discoverable facts and did not establish a constitutional error. The dissenting member argued for granting the petition when a death row inmate claims actual innocence. Davis's petition was transferred to the United States District Court for the Southern District of Georgia for further review. The district court is instructed to receive testimony and make findings of fact on whether new evidence establishes the petitioner's innocence.
